awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Novel Techniques and Applications in Catalysis Research Development and Molecular Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site award to the University of Pennsylvania, located in Philadelphia, PA, supports the training of 10 undergraduate students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2020-2022. In this program, funded by the Division of Chemistry, undergraduate participants develop diverse approaches to improving chemical reactions under the mentorship of faculty and graduate students or postdoctoral associates. An aspect unique to this site is that participants also gain exposure to high throughput experimentation (HTE) methods, training that is often limited to industry. Exposure to HTE provides a distinct experience for participants, one with long-term leverage into both academic and industrial career pathways. Participants take part in regular professional development activities where they hone their communication skills, explore career paths, and learn about responsible research conduct, preparing them for advanced degrees in STEM. 

The research projects available for participants span a significant space across catalysis: method development, catalyst development, and synthetic applications, as well as extension into molecular dynamics and beyond. This program recruits students nationwide, with an emphasis on underrepresented student groups. A wide raging network of industrial and academic collaborations expose participants to a variety of viable career pathways with the goal of sustaining a diverse and competitive chemical science workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hosted at the University of Pennsylvania by the Department of Chemistry, this NSF sponsored REU program provided the opportunity for 30 undergraduate students to perform research with world class chemists in the area of catalysis and computational chemistry.  The students ranged from having completed their freshmen years to having finished their junior years.  The REU cohorts ranged from 83–92% self-identified URM (as defined by the NSF).  Given that nearly all the REU students that now graduated from their undergraduate institutions applied to PhD graduate programs, this NSF supported program is successfully contributing to the overall diversity of the PhD level chemical community.  

 

As part of their training and development, Penn Chemistry REU students are required to present their research findings in oral format to the graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, faculty, and staff of Penn Chemistry both at the midpoint of their research stint and in the final week of their research program.  Preparation of their PPT slides is done with input from their research team.  The REU students are encouraged to practice their presentations in front of their faculty mentors and their research groups during group meetings to polish their slide decks and hone their presentation skills.  REU students, with input from their day-to-day mentors, their faculty mentors, and the REU Co-PI and PI, are mandated to write a scientific final report on their REU research experience.  This report is in the format of a manuscript for publication.  It is carefully reviewed by the co-PI, who offers suggestions for improvement.  Finally, the students also prepare a poster to present to the Penn chemistry community during a poster session/social gathering with food and non-alcoholic drinks supplied by the Department of Chemistry.

 

For professional development opportunities, students participated in seminars from Penn faculty and staff on topics ranging from research ethics to documenting experimental activities and observations in laboratory notebooks to safety to literature searches and writing a powerful personal statement for school graduate applications.  

 

The diversity of research areas of the faculty mentors in the Penn Chemistry REU range from synthesis of photo switches, computational chemistry of heterogeneous catalysts, organometallic reaction mechanisms, methods development under catalysis, catalytic nitrogen fixation, lanthanide chemistry (reactivity and separation), preparation of glass-forming materials and the study of their vapor deposited films.  The vast majority of these projects involve catalysis.  The breadth of research topics enables chemistry students with different research interests to pursue their chemical curiosity.  This allows them to have fun because chemistry is fascinating and should be fun!

 

Our REU program is structured so that the Penn Chemistry REU students have ample opportunities to interact with other young scientists from different REU programs at Penn.  Of course, in any gathering of scientists, the talk eventually turns to science, giving the Chemistry REU students exposure to research projects in related disciplines performed by their peers.  By hosting social events for the REU students, Penn Chemistry fosters a stimulating social and intellectual environment where cross-discipline connections can be formed and scientific excitement augmented.  Based on the students’ educational opportunities, research experiences, scientific and social activities, the overall student evaluation of the program have been positive and helped the leadership team to optimize the students’ and mentors’ experiences.  Furthermore, the leadership team has been impressed with the evolution of the REU students, who clearly grew in research skill, scientific inquiry and overall confidence over the course of the program.  

 

Of the students in our REU program, 100% of those slated to finish their chemistry degrees have now graduated from their home institutions (or will graduate by Dec. 2023).  Of the 15 REU students who graduated and were eligible to apply for graduate school programs at the writing of this report, 13 are currently enrolled in graduate school programs in chemistry (87%).  These results indicate that the Penn Chemistry REU program is having a lasting and significant impact.  Thus, our program clearly contributes to the nation’s chemical base, the diversification of the chemical sciences, and the well-being of society at large.  We are very grateful to the NSF for supporting the Penn Chemistry REU program and look forward to another 3 years of producing diverse and high quality students for graduate programs around the country.
